messages.content: So my psychiatrist did an eeg and some tests where I had to watch a tunnel turn left and right and press buttons and some sound and buttons and other things like that and in the end he said I have ADD - what is that test test g

What youâ€™re describing sounds like a **neuropsychological attention test**, often combined with EEG (electroencephalography) to measure brainwave activity.  

The â€œtunnel turning left and right and pressing buttonsâ€ and â€œsounds and pressing buttonsâ€ are very characteristic of **Continuous Performance Tests (CPTs)** or related computerized attention tasks. These tests measure things like:  

- **Sustained attention** (can you stay focused over time)  
- **Selective attention** (can you respond only to certain targets, not distractors)  
- **Impulsivity** (do you press too quickly on the wrong things)  
- **Reaction time** (speed and consistency of responses)  

Some well-known versions include:  
- **TOVA (Test of Variables of Attention)** â€“ widely used in ADHD/ADD assessment, often with simple shapes or sounds as â€œgo/no-goâ€ tasks.  
- **QbTest** â€“ combines a CPT with motion tracking to detect hyperactivity.  
- **CPT-III** â€“ a computerized test with visual and auditory stimuli.  

The EEG part is sometimes used alongside these to look at **brainwave patterns** (like theta/beta ratios), which some clinicians use as additional evidence for ADHD/ADD.

You likely did a **Continuous Performance Test (CPT)**â€”probably something like the **TOVA or QbTest**â€”together with an EEG recording. These tests donâ€™t diagnose by themselves, but they provide objective data about attention, focus, and impulsivity, which your psychiatrist interpreted in the context of your history and symptoms to give you an ADD diagnosis.

He said he saw two regions get activated in my brain instead of the normal one region which was hallmark of add what is that about

Ah â€” that detail helps a lot.  

What your psychiatrist is probably referring to is something that comes from the **EEG/qEEG (quantitative EEG) side of the test**, not the button-press part.  

Hereâ€™s whatâ€™s going on in plain terms:  

- In tasks that require focus, **neurotypical brains** tend to show **dominant activation in one main attention control network** (often fronto-parietal, with prefrontal cortex leading).  
- In people with **ADD/ADHD**, research shows that the brain sometimes has to **â€œrecruitâ€ extra regions** to get the same task done. Instead of one streamlined network handling focus, **two (or more) regions light up**.  

This is often interpreted as:  
- **Less efficient neural processing** â†’ the brain uses a â€œworkaroundâ€ by pulling in extra areas.  
- **Compensatory activation** â†’ your brain tries to cover for lapses in attention control by engaging other regions not normally used as heavily.  

Different studies highlight slightly different areas, but the common story is:  
- **Frontal lobes (especially prefrontal cortex)**: main executive control hub.  
- **Parietal or temporal regions**: may light up more in ADD brains when trying to sustain focus, showing that attention is being â€œspread outâ€ instead of streamlined.  

ğŸ‘‰ So when your psychiatrist said *â€œtwo regions instead of one is the hallmark of ADDâ€*, he meant:  
Your brain shows **split activation patterns** on EEG during attention tasks, which matches the known neurophysiological signatures of ADD.  

Itâ€™s not that your brain is â€œbrokenâ€ â€” itâ€™s that it takes **extra steps** to do whatâ€™s automatic for others. Thatâ€™s why you may feel like you work harder just to stay on task.

Whatâ€™s the research on using qeeg for add diagnosis itâ€™s usually qualitative

Hereâ€™s what the latest research says about using **quantitative EEG (qEEG)** for diagnosing ADD (also known as ADHD inattentive type):

---

###  Reliability and Limitations of the Theta-Beta Ratio (TBR)

- **Early promiseâ€¦ but fading consistency.** Early studies suggested that an elevated **theta/beta ratio (TBR)** could reliably indicate ADHD. Yet, follow-ups found much weaker performanceâ€”with sensitivity around **63%** and specificity around **58%** îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search0îˆ.
- **Age matters (a lot).** In children, this ratio may show mild correlation with symptoms; in adolescents and adults, the correlation drops or even reverses îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search0îˆ.
- **A shrinking diagnostic signal.** Meta-analyses show that the initial promising effect sizes diminished over time as studies became more rigorous îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search0îˆ.
- **Nonspecific findings.** Elevated theta activity isnâ€™t unique to ADHDâ€”itâ€™s seen with drowsiness, other behavioral disorders, and even benign EEG variants îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search0îˆ.
- **Official reviews remain skeptical.** Aetna, for instance, labels qEEG for ADHD â€œexperimentalâ€ due to insufficient evidence of clinical usefulness îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search9îˆ.

---

###  Clinical Studies and Diagnostic Tools

- **NEBA system (FDA-reviewed).** In a pivotal study:
  - In adolescents (12â€“17), sensitivity was **89%**, specificity **87%**, PPV (positive predictive value) **81%**, NPV **93%**.
  - In children (6â€“11), sensitivity was **79%**, specificity **97%**, PPV **96%**, NPV **82%**.
  - Researchers estimated that adding NEBA to clinical evaluation could boost diagnostic accuracy from **61% to 88%** îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search12îˆ.
  - **But caveats apply**: the consensus diagnosis did not include direct interviews, the study lacked an intention-to-treat design, and larger follow-up analyses questioned the theta/beta ratioâ€™s diagnostic value îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search12îˆ‚turn0search9îˆ.

- **Other validated findings:**
  - Some methods combining **IVA + CPT (continuous performance tests)** with qEEG achieved detection accuracy up to **82.1%** îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search3îˆ.
  - A systematic review highlighted a wavelet-synchronization and brain network analysis approach that reached **95.6% diagnostic accuracy** in a small adult sample (n=47), though such results remain exploratory îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search2îˆ.
  - A recent pilot study reaffirmed potential sensitivity of qEEG differences in children with ADHD versus controlsâ€”but this is early-stage and not definitive îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search4îˆ.

---

###  Machine Learning & Multimodal Innovations

- **Virtual reality + multimodal data.** A 2024 study combining eye tracking, EEG, motion data, and behavior in a VR attention task reached **81% accuracy**â€”but interestingly, EEG features didnâ€™t contribute significantly îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search10îˆ.
- **ML-based web app (DETEC-ADHD).** This prototype system integrates EEG-based TBR with psychological and personal data. It achieved **100% accuracy in children** and **90% in adults**â€”though its sample size was extremely limited (20 participants) îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search15îˆ.

---

###  Summary Table

| Technique / System               | Diagnostic Accuracy              | Key Limitations |
|----------------------------------|----------------------------------|------------------|
| TBR (theta/beta ratio)           | ~63% sensitivity / ~58% specificity | Inconsistent findings; non-specific; age-dependent |
| NEBA system (FDA study)          | Sensitivity: 79â€“89%, Specificity: 87â€“97% | Study design issues; questioned reproducibility |
| qEEG + IVA/CPT                   | ~82% accuracy                    | Needs more replication |
| Wavelet/network EEG analysis     | ~95.6% accuracy (small study)     | Exploratory, small sample size |
| VR + multimodal (eye, motion)    | ~81% accuracy (EEG non-contributing) | EEG may add little |
| DETEC-ADHD (ML + EEG)            | 100% children / 90% adults       | Very small sample; preliminary |

---

###  Overall Takeaway

- **qEEG is not a standalone diagnostic tool.** It shows potentialâ€”especially when integrated with behavioral testsâ€”but its reliability varies.
- **Best used as a supplement, not a replacement.** Clinical guidelines emphasize a comprehensive evaluation (history, interviews, rating scales) over EEG alone îˆ€citeîˆ‚turn0search9îˆ‚turn0search12îˆ.
- **Emerging methods show promiseâ€”but require more validation.** New techniques like ML-based multimodal analysis are exciting, yet still very much in the research phase.

Whatâ€™s Iva and neba? I donâ€™t know these things and how they work and what they test for

Great question â€” let me break both of these down clearly, since they sound like alphabet soup at first.  

---

## **IVA (Integrated Visual and Auditory CPT)**

- **What it is:**  
  IVA is a type of **Continuous Performance Test (CPT)**. Itâ€™s a computer-based task where you respond to certain visual or auditory cues and withhold responses to others.  
- **How it works:**  
  You sit in front of a computer. A sequence of **numbers, letters, or sounds** appears or plays. Youâ€™re instructed, for example:  
  - â€œPress the space bar when you see/hear a 1, but not when you see/hear a 2.â€  
  - Sometimes it flips: press on 2, not 1.  
  This runs for about 15 minutes with varying speed and distractions.  
- **What it measures:**  
  - **Sustained attention** (can you keep up for the whole test?)  
  - **Response control / impulsivity** (do you press when you shouldnâ€™t?)  
  - **Consistency** (are your reaction times stable or all over the place?)  
  - **Auditory vs visual attention** (some people have more trouble with one channel).  
- **Use in ADD/ADHD:**  
  People with ADD often show **more variable reaction times, more false alarms, and more misses**, which suggests lapses in focus and/or impulsivity.  

---

## **NEBA (Neuropsychiatric EEG-Based Assessment Aid)**

- **What it is:**  
  NEBA is a **qEEG system** that was FDA-cleared (in 2013) as an *adjunctive* tool for diagnosing ADHD in kids and teens.  
- **How it works:**  
  A cap or electrodes are placed on your scalp for a short resting EEG (no tasks, usually eyes open/closed). It calculates the **ratio of theta to beta brainwave activity**:  
  - **Theta waves** (4â€“7 Hz): linked to drowsiness, mind-wandering.  
  - **Beta waves** (13â€“21 Hz): linked to alert focus and problem-solving.  
  - **Theta/Beta Ratio (TBR):** High ratios (lots of theta, not enough beta) were historically associated with ADHD.  
- **What it measures:**  
  Just this **wave ratio** â€” nothing about behavior.  
- **Use in ADD/ADHD:**  
  If the ratio is above a certain threshold, it may *support* a clinical ADHD diagnosis. But itâ€™s not definitive: other conditions (sleep issues, anxiety, etc.) can also alter theta/beta activity.  

---

### **Key Difference**

- **IVA** = Behavioral test of how your attention system *performs under demand* (reaction time, errors).  
- **NEBA** = Brainwave measurement of how your brainâ€™s *attention networks are idling*.  

Doctors sometimes use both together: **IVA shows the behavior, NEBA shows the physiology**. But neither is considered sufficient for diagnosis on its own â€” theyâ€™re â€œadjunctsâ€ to history, interviews, and rating scales.
